title: Frustration and fixation
creator_contributor_role: University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Laboratory of Psychometric & Evaluation Research, production company
subject_group: Education, Instruction, Teaching & Schools/Psychology - Study and teaching
Food, Health, Lifestyle, Medicine, Psychology & Safety/Frustration
Food, Health, Lifestyle, Medicine, Psychology & Safety/Psychology - Study and teaching

Economics, Philosophy, Politics, Religion & Sociology/Animal experimentation
description: Documents Maier's thesis that frustration leads to fixation and other bizarre sysmptoms. Shows a modified Lashley jumping apparatus and describes the process of teaching rats to jump. Frustrated animals finally assigned to soluble problems persist in fixations in spite of opening correct doors, and although walking trials demonstrate that they know the correct choice. Includes demonstrations of catatonic and neurotic behaviour.
